Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List:
axiomatic set theory
operations on sets
proofs involving sets
I learned basic proof techniques and the axioms of Z-F set theory.
I learned to write proofs in Mathematics. I learned how to write in set builder notation. I learned the foundations of basic axiomatic set theory.
This class teaches the rudiments of set theory: the basic ZFC axioms and intro to proof.
very axiomatic/lemma based proof writing, can seem redundant but its a skill not emphasized in other math courses
You'll cover roughly the first 5 chapters Hrbacek's Set Theory textbook.
I learned the basics of theory, including axiomatic constructions, relations, numbers, and counting.
Basic knowledge regarding set theory, including fundamental axions, relations, functions, orderings, natural numbers, inductive theorem, and so on.

I learned the basics of axiomatic set theory, starting with the first axioms like the axiom of existence and the axiom of comprehension, and up through Cantor's Theorem. We talked about relations and functions, equivalences, orderings, natural numbers, and cardinality.
All about set theory!

Interesting content
self-teaching most of the material, lectures tend not to be helpful, the textbook is very mediocre, there are limited resources for support in the class
The instructor should aim to cover the content on the problem sets before they are due. Having to learn from the textbook everything is fine, but that is something I can do without taking a  course.

Strengths: interesting material, very different from other Math courses. Slow paced so easy to keep up.
Weaknesses: hard to do well if you do not have a strong background in proof writing, material not presented in lectures (you basically have to teach yourself the course from the textbook).

This course should be recommended to freshmen as an alternative to math 230, especially for kids who have never seen proofs before. This class could be a fantastic introduction to higher mathematical thinking.
few problem sets which is both good and bad, lectures are kind of a regurgitation of the textbook instead of engaging with new practice but the professor is very iwlling to help outside of class

This course could be improved with more frequent due dates for smaller assignments. The same amount of work, just more spread out. There should also be a peer tutor and I believe that the university should hire a student to type the lecture notes for the professor.

Strengths: the subject matter is itself very interesting. The workload was manageable, and the problem sets were helpful. The grader was also nice and provided constructive feedback.

Weaknesses: Professor Zuckerman, while a kind teacher and funny guy, taught the class in a way that did not allow the best parts of set theory to shine through. Proofs in class were confusing, the pace was slow (in a way that detracted, I think, from the overall experience), and the exams---while challenging---were also quite different from the kinds of questions/approaches that the textbook emphasized.
The textbook is not very well written, but the course in general is relatively organized.
Little correlation between what is taught in class and what is asked on PSETS.

This course moved very slowly. That could be a good thing, because Prof. Zuckerman definitely wanted to be very thorough about everything, but it means that you really need to know your stuff come exam time. The lectures could also be a bit difficult to stay engaged with because they were so slow, but it does make it so that it's not too difficult to follow along. 

I think a main weakness of this course was that we only had the one textbook and our class notes for reference and there wasn't really much help available outside of class. Zuckerman did hold office hours and those could be helpful, but they were best for if you had a question about a specific problem on the pset or on some example from the lectures and they also moved quite slowly. It would have been very helpful if there could have been a peer tutor to help outside of class, since the material is very different from other types of math that most students had taken before.
Lectures are extremely clear and Professor Zuckerman always provides examples. Problem sets solidify what was taught in class. The class could cover more; I think we dragged at times.

The course content is interesting, but you should be comfortable teaching yourself the material. The second midterm, the material was fairly difficult to predict, which was frustrating. The first midterm was exactly what we'd learned in PSETs and in class though. There were 4 psets in this semester, and the workload is low. Course is backloaded, however.
No. You will likely stop going to class once you realize that you're better off just reading the book on your own and working on the problem sets during lecture.
I would only recommend this course to students who LOVE Math or who need the class to fulfill their requirement for the Math and Philosophy major.

This class is amazing. Don't expect to learn a lot, but expect to learn a few topics very thoroughly. Professor Zuckerman is a fantastic prof who cares about your introduction to a topic he loves very deeply. Take this class if you're new to advanced math because it offers a good introduction to proofs. Take this class as an easy 5th class too.
only if required
If you're a math or a math and philosophy major then the course is definitely relevant to you. Otherwise I'd say just read the textbook.

I would overall, because I love set theory as a subject. But know that this is a slow/compromised introduction to it, and that it will likely be frustrating in several respects, not least of which are constantly shifting expectations and confusing class sessions.
Yes. I think sets are interesting topic to learn.
Yes. Zuckerman is the best professor I've every had.

I would recommend it if you're very interested in mathematical logic, but not if you're just a math student looking for another math credit. Zuckerman is a nice guy and some parts of the material are kind of interesting, but I found this course frustrating. It wasn't so much that the math we did was necessarily harder than other math that I had taken before, but that some of it was hard to get used to and I didn't feel like there were a lot of resources available if I had trouble with something or wanted a little extra help on a problem set. It ended up being that day to day the class was fairly easy and the problem sets weren't too heavy or frequent, but then I wouldn't do well on the tests because they could be quite challenging and Zuckerman graded kind of harshly.
Yes. Content is interesting and the class is not too challenging.
